Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Scaling Operational Intelligence Graphs with GPU Clouds
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will, most directly, be to provide institutions such as banks and national defense agencies with visibility into their graph-足centric security and operations data, and thereby improve their robustness and resilience. Farther out, enabling visualization of larger graphs will also aid non-足IT uses, such as to help financial analysts understand markets, marketing and sales teams understand customers, and precision medicine researchers understand gene interactions. Furthermore, generalizing the underlying GPU cloud infrastructure to scale interactive visualizations beyond graphs will help even more types of analysts comprehend data from an even wider variety of data sources. Likewise, generalizing the proposed GPU cloud infrastructure will also aid non足-visual analytic tasks, such as machine learning over big data.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project's goal is to scale visual graph analysis to enterprise level security analytics. Modern graph visualization tools handle at most 50,000 nodes, but many enterprises manage over a million devices and services. The proposed innovation scales graph visualizations to 1足-2 magnitudes more data. The visualizations interact with a GPU cluster for analysis (e.g., cross-filtering), visual layout (e.g., ForceAtlas2 and edge bundling), and rendering. Key to Phase I is establishing the technical feasibility of building and deploying the distributed GPU cloud architecture. The architecture utilizes novel GPU components and optimizations for: (i) GPU analytics (ii) GPU-accelerated visual layouts; (iii) cloud GPU resource management; and (iv) a streaming renderer to draw more while maintaining perceived quality and responsiveness. In collaboration with pilot customers, the views and workflows necessary for minimal viable security analytics usage will be identified and prototyped.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project to establish the feasibility of scaling operational intelligence through GPU client/cloud acceleration succeeded beyond expectations. The immediate goal of proving feasibility for Phase II was achieved. More broadly, the project proved the feasibility of a more scalable approach to interactive big data visualization and graph analytics, and demonstrated a new capability for addressing urgent infrastructure problems, including pressing ones in cybersecurity.

 

The core technology successfully demonstrated by this project was increasing the amount of data that can be interactively visualized in common settings. Scaling visualizations is important because most kinds of interactive visualization systems already cannot handle typical data volumes, and the amount of data facing data analysts is steadily increasing. Through a novel approach of GPU client/cloud acceleration, our prototype handled 10-1000X more data than possible with current commercial alternatives. Furthermore, the prototype was built to only require commodity technology like web browsers and public cloud system, meaning that most data analysts will be able to benefit from the approach. The project included an early access program, and culminated in daily use by analysts from across different scientific and commercial disciplines.

 

Successfully scaling visual analytics  for graph data featured prominently in the project. The platform was used both to show more graph nodes and edges than possible in comparable projects, and interactively cluster and analyze more data than possible in other systems. Users reported benefiting from both of these capabilities for problems such as protein analysis, cybersecurity, data center operations, supply chain analysis, communication analysis, social network analysis, and more. Early prototype users  reported back benefits for their jobs as scientists, data analysts, and non-profit workers.

 

The project showed that the important application area of cybersecurity is particularly well-served by its techniques. For example, when applied to analytic workloads from some of the world’s largest enterprises, the project successfully visualized situational awareness for systems of hundreds of thousands of devices with hundreds of millions of daily security-relevant events. Under the guidance of security analysts, a series of such use cases were proven. The successful demonstrations contributed towards multiple commercial contracts and partnerships, and multiple standing-room-only presentations at industry events. Of note, federal agencies contracted services around the project.

 

In summary, the Phase I project met and exceeded the outcome expectations of the program.
